For the growth on the Ag (111) surface, a silicene grain of 25 Si atoms arranged in hexagons with a Si atom adhered at the zigzag edge ( Figure 8a) or the armchair edge ( Figure 8b) was placed on an Ag substrate of four (111) layers with each consisting of 48 Ag atoms in a (6 × 8) supercell, and the geometry was optimized with the bottom layer of the Ag substrate fixed. The adhered Si atom (and the Si atom denoted by a square in Figure 8a,b) was moved step by step to produce the potential
U ′
, and the configurational integral was obtained by Equation (21) with
N 0
= 25. As shown in Figure 8c, the FEZ and FEA decreased with the temperature up to 2000 K, while the DFE increased slightly from −0.022 eV up to 0.056 eV. In the temperature range from 200 K to 580 K, the DFE as less than 0.01 eV, and the DFE equaled zero for 400 K. According to the thermal dynamics, the probability for the future deposited atoms adhering to either the zigzag or the armchair edge was equal when the substrate was kept at 400 K, which should be the most optimum temperature for the silicene grain growing to form a continuous graphene-like structure. In previous experiments [ 3, 27], the optimum temperature was 493–580 K, which was about one hundred Kelvin higher than our prediction.
